Facultad de Ciencias Químicas, Casilla 160C, Universidad de Concepción Chile Half-substituted perovskites LaFe0.5Ni0.5O3, LaFe0.5Co0.5O3 and LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 were used as precursors to synthesize, by an exsolution process, reduced catalysts for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of m-cresol at 200 °C and 30 bar H2 pressure. The calcined perovskites and exsolved catalysts were characterized by AAS, H2-TPR, N2 physisorption, XRD, XPS, TEM and NH3-TPD techniques. The characterization results show large differences in the reducibility of perovskites in the presence or absence of Fe. In the case of the exsolved catalyst without Fe content (LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3), the formation of metallic Co0 and Ni0 is detected, while the exsolved catalysts containing Fe (LaFe0.5Co0.5O3, LaFe0.5Ni0.5O3) were not reducible in H2 below 500 °C. The higher m-cresol conversion, initial reaction rate and hydrogenation (HYD) activity of the exsolved LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst were attributed to the presence of highly dispersed surface species of metallic Co0 and Ni0. The formation of the major product, 3-methylcyclohexanol, over the LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst was independent of the reaction temperature in the range of 150 – 200 °C. However, the hydrogenation activity increased with increasing H2 pressure between 20 and 50 bar. The exsolved LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst shows no loss of catalytic activity after 5 cycles without regeneration, and post-reaction characterization demonstrates that the surface composition remains stable after five reaction cycles, with no detectable leaching of nickel and cobalt. Graphical Abstract Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Exsolved catalysts M-cresol Hydrogenation Biomass Perovskites Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Catalytic transformation of oxygenated aromatics into value-added chemicals and fuels is a central challenge in biomass upgrading. Among these, m-cresol (2-methylphenol) is widely recognized as a model compound for lignin-derived phenolics due to its representative structure, which includes both a hydroxyl group and a methyl-substituted aromatic ring. Efficient hydrogenation (HYD) and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of m-cresol enables the production of industrially relevant value-added chemicals such as 3-methylcyclohexanone (MCol), 3-methylcyclohexane (MCha), toluene and benzene [1–4]. These reactions have received considerable attention when catalyzed by noble metal. These catalysts often exhibit high activity and selectivity to hydrogenated products [5,6]. However, high costs, limited availability, propensity for sintering and/or leaching are significant drawbacks to the use of noble metal catalysts, leading to interests in non-noble based catalysts. Nie et al. [7] reported that the catalytic conversion of m-cresol using in situ reduced supported Ni, Fe and FeNi oxide catalysts exhibited different selectivity upon the presence of iron, being Ni/SiO2 mainly selective to 3-methylcyclohexanone while Fe/SiO2 and FeNi/SiO2 to toluene, suggesting that iron promotes direct deoxygenation (DDO) pathways. Abreu et al. [8] reports the dependence of Ni particle size in the conversion of m-cresol in vapor phase at 573 K under atmospheric pressure. The DDO rate increased 10-fold as the Ni particle size decreased from 9 nm to 1 nm forming toluene as the main product, while the HYD and hydrogenolysis (HYG) rates increased moderately forming phenol and 3-methylcyclohexanone, respectively. These studies underline the importance of both metal composition and support properties in controlling product selectivity. Notably, all these studies have been conducted under gas-phase conditions, leaving a significant gap in our understanding of the catalytic behavior under liquid-phase hydrogenation. There is still a limited understanding of how catalyst structure and redox behavior influence the interplay between ring hydrogenation and C–O bond cleavage under liquid-phase hydrogenation conditions. Perovskites-type oxides with a general formula ABO3, where A and B are cations of different ionic radius, usually metal transition have attracted significant attention as catalyst precursor due to their structural flexibility, redox activity, and thermal stability. These materials can accommodate a wide range of transition metals at B-site [9], enabling the rational design of compositions that combine multiple catalytic functions. Additionally, their ability to undergo partial reduction while maintaining the perovskite framework makes them suitable candidates for reactions that require both metal and oxygen-mediated steps, such as hydrogenation and hydrodeoxygenation. In this regard, over the past decade, the redox-driven exsolution method has emerged as a powerful method for the synthesis of active and structurally robust metal nanoparticles supported on oxide matrices [10]. In this approach, some catalytically active metal cations (e.g., Ni, Co, Fe) can be initially incorporated into the B-sites of perovskite-type oxides, and upon thermal treatment under reducing conditions, these cations migrate to the surface and can be exsolved as metallic nanoparticles strongly anchored to the oxide matrix [11,12]. This method contrasts with conventional impregnation techniques, which often result in nanoparticles with weaker metal-support interactions, lower stability, and higher leaching risk in liquid-phase reactions. Exsolution offers unique advantages, including strong metal–support interactions, resistance to sintering, and structural reversibility under redox cycling [13]. The exsolved nanoparticles are typically socketed into the host lattice, providing enhanced anchorage and thermal stability, and are often more catalytically active due to strain-induced effects and epitaxial alignment [14]. Furthermore, exsolution enables precise control over the size, distribution, and composition of nanoparticles by adjusting parameters such as the host lattice stoichiometry, reduction temperature, atmosphere, and reduction time [15]. This level of tunability is difficult to achieve using conventional impregnation routes. The growing body of literature on exsolved materials has demonstrated their versatility across catalytic, electrochemical, and energy conversion applications, motivating their further exploration in biomass-derived molecule transformations. For substituted AB1-xFexO3 ex-solved perovskites it has been reported that the stoichiometric amount of Fe(x) in the B site does not increase the activity but determines the selectivity of the ex-solved bimetallic nanoparticles [16]. An important property of metallic catalysts is their selectivity, discussed by Umar et al. [17] in substituted LaCoxNi1-xO3 perovskites, reporting that the Ni4+/Ni2+ redox pair in the perovskite enhanced the activity of the ex-solved catalyst due to the creation of oxygen vacancies. Regarding biomass-related hydrogenation reactions in liquid phase, ex-solved LaNiO3 perovskites have been reported for hydrogenation of xylose in liquid batch reactor [18]. The most important advantage of these partially reduced perovskites compared to the traditional alumina supported catalysts is their large resistance to leaching in water medium [19]. Escalona et al. [20] reported the impact of cerium incorporation in the catalytic transformation of guaiacol using nickel exsolved La1-xCexNiO3 (0.0 ≤ xCe ≤ 0.9) perovskites. The authors concluded that the Ni-reduced catalyst were effective catalysts in the conversion of guaiacol to cyclohexanol, and particularly for the catalyst with xCe = 0.5 a 50 % of selectivity towards cyclohexanol. This result was attributed to the formation of the perovskite structure and an increase in thermal resistance in a reducing atmosphere for the presence of CeO2. Despite these promising examples, to our knowledge, no reports have addressed the use of exsolved perovskites in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of m-cresol, a highly relevant model for lignin-derived phenolics. This constitutes a significant gap, particularly considering the severe leaching and stability challenges of non-noble metal catalysts under liquid conditions. The aim of this work is to promote the applicability of half B-substituted exsolved perovskites (LaFe0.5Co0.5O3, LaFe0.5Ni0.5O3 and LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3) to be used as catalysts on the conversion of m-cresol. The effect of the reaction temperature, H2 pressure and the operational stability were also investigated. 2 Methodology 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts Half substituted LaFe0.5Ni0.5O3, LaFe0.5Co0.5O3 and LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 perovskites prepared by the citrate method [21] were used as precursors to prepare metallic reduced catalysts by exsolution treatment. For a better comparison pure LaNiO3, LaFeO3 and LaCoO3 exsolved catalysts were also synthesized. To synthesize the perovskites, stoichiometric amounts of an aqueous solution of the nitrates of the corresponding metals were added to an aqueous solution of citric acid under stirring for 15 min at room temperature (Table S1). The resulting dissolution slowly evaporated at 70 °C for 1 h under vacuum in a rotary evaporator. The obtained gel was dried in a vacuum oven at 150 °C for 12 h. The final powder was ground and calcined in air to eliminate the remaining organic precursors, at a heating rate of 3 °C min−1 to 700 °C for 4 h. For the exsolution treatment, the calcined perovskites were reduced under pure hydrogen flow (50 mL min−1) at 500 °C for 4 h and passivated in 5 % O2/N2 flow (30 mL min−1) for 1 h with the reactor immersed in a cryostat bath, and then for an additional 1.5 h at room temperature. Finally, the exsolved perovskites were stabilized at room temperature. 2.2 Catalysts characterization Metal content in the calcined perovskites was determined by atomic adsorption spectroscopy (AAS) using a Perkin Elmer instrument 3100 model. Prior to analysis, the sample was dissolved in concentrated hydrochloric acid and subjected to hot plate digestion. The reduction characteristics of the calcined perovskites were examined using a TPR/TPD 2900 Micromeritics instrument fitted with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to the hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements, approximately 50 mg of catalysts were loaded in a U-shaped quartz reactor and dried in flowing He (50 mL min−1) at 110 °C for 0.5 h to remove any weakly-adsorbed water molecules. H2-TPR was performed from 25 °C to 800 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1 under 5 vol% H2/Ar (50 mL min−1). The effluent gas was passed through a cold trap filled with a mixture of isopropanol and liquid nitrogen to remove water vapor before entering the TCD detector. Nitrogen physisorption isotherms of the calcined perovskites and exsolved catalysts were obtained at −196 °C using a Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 instrument to evaluate the BET specific surface area (SBET). Prior to the measurements, the samples were degassed under vacuum at 200 °C for 3 h in a nitrogen flow. SBET was calculated from the adsorption branch in the range 0.05 ≤ P/Po≤ 0.25. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the calcined and catalysts were obtained using a Rigaku 3700 powder diffractometer equipped with a Ni-filtered (radiation source CuKα λ=1.5406 Å), operated at 30 kV/10 mA and a solid state LinxEye detector. The standard scan parameters were 10–90° 2θ with a step size of 0.02° and a counting time of 0.4 s per step. The instrumental contribution to line broadening was accounted for by measuring a silicon standard (NIST SRM 640e) using an identical optical configuration. Identification of the phases was achieved by reference to ICDD and JSPDS files. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were recorded on a VG Escalab 200 R electron spectrometer using a Mg Kα (1253.6 eV) photon source. The exsolved catalysts were pre-reduced insitu at 300 °C in the pre-treatment chamber of the spectrometer to remove the passivation layer. The binding energies (BE) were referenced to the C 1 s level of carbon support at 284.8 eV. An estimated error of ± 0.1 eV can be assumed for all measurements. Intensities of the peaks were calculated from the respective peak areas after background subtraction and spectrum fitting by the standard computer based statistical analysis which included fitting the experimental spectra to a sum of Gaussian and Lorentzian lines (90G-10L). Relative surface atomic ratios were determined from the corresponding peak areas, corrected with tabulated sensitivity factors, with a precision of 7 %. TEM micrographs were obtained in a JEOL Model JEM-1200 EX II instrument. The average particle size was calculated using ImageJ software by analyzing more than 200 individual particles. The acidity of the calcined perovskites and exsolved catalysts was determined by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD). The experiments were performed in a Micromeritics Autochem II system equipped with a TCD. Prior to analysis the dried and reduced samples were placed in a quartz reactor, flushed under He flow of 50 mL min−1 at 40 °C for 0.5 h, subjected to ammonia pulses at 40 °C until saturation of surface, and then cooled to room temperature under He flow of 50 mL min−1. Once the baseline was stabilized, TPD-NH3 measurements were performed while the temperature was increased to 1000 °C at 10 °C min−1. 2.3 Catalytic tests The hydrogenation reaction was carried out in a stainless-steal reactor operating in batch mode (Parr model 4561). In each experiment, 0.250 g of exsolved catalyst, 0.232 mol L−1 of m-cresol in 80.0 mL dodecane with n-hexadecane as an internal standard was added to the vessel reactor. After sealed, the reactor was purged with N2 flow for 15 min to remove residual oxygen gas inside the reactor. Still under N2 atmosphere, the reactor was heated up to the desired reaction temperature of (150 – 200 °C) under continuous stirring at 650 rpm to minimize mass transfer limitations [22]. Then, H2 pressure was adjusted (20–50 bar) and kept constant during the experiment. Aliquots of 0.1 mL were periodically withdrawn during the evolution reaction. The reaction products were analyzed by gas chromatography (Nexis GC 2023, Shimadzu) with flame-ionization detector (FID) and an RTX-5B column (Perkin Elmer, 30 m x 0.32 mm×1.0 µm film thickness). The products were also identified by their column retention time in comparison with available standards. The operational stability was evaluated through recycling tests. After each recycling, the catalyst was recovered by filtration, washed with 40.0 mL of methanol, and dried at 110 °C for 12 h. The conversion (%) of m-cresol and yield of product (%) are defined as follows in Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) X T ( % ) = mol of m − cresol reacted mol of m − cresol initial x 100 (2) Yield of product i ( % ) = mol of product i mol of m − cresol initial x 100 The specific rate, rs (molgcat −1s−1), was calculated from the initial slope of the plot of m-cresol conversion as a function of time, according to Eq. (3): (3) r s = ( b x n ) m where b is the initial slope of conversion vs. time plot (s−1), n is the initial moles of m-cresol in the solution (mol), and m the mass of catalyst (g). The selectivity (%) to the product i (Si) was determined at 10 % of m-cresol conversion, according to Eq. (4): (4) S i % = X i X T x 100 where Xi is the percentage of product formation i, and XT is the m-cresol conversion. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Half-substituted LaFe0.5Ni0.5O3, LaFe0.5Co0.5O3 and LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 exsolved catalysts 3.1.1 Characterization The measured metal contents of the calcined perovskites agree well with the nominal contents (Table S2), indicating the successful synthesis. The H2-TPR profiles of the calcined perovskites are shown in Fig. 1. For LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3, the profile was fitted to three deconvoluted reduction peaks (Figure S1): i) at ∼360 °C, linked to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ and Ni3+ to Ni2+ species; ii) at ∼470 °C, which corresponds to the reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0; and iii) at ∼500 °C, corresponding to the reduction of Co2+ to Co0 that can be masked by the concurrent reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0. In contrast, for LaFe0.5Co0.5O3 and LaFe0.5Ni0.5O3 perovskites only a single well-defined peak appeared at ∼340 °C and ∼380 °C, assigned to the reduction of Co3+/Co2+ and Ni3+/Ni2+ species, respectively. Furthermore, it is observed for both perovskites that there is a significant displacement of the reduction peak of metallic Co and Ni particles at higher reduction temperatures centered at 800 °C [25]. Considering that La (III) is a non-reducible cation, no reduction of Fe3+ to Fe0 in LaFeO3 perovskite was detected. It has been reported that Fe3+ is highly stable and requires large amounts of energy to reduce it to Fe0 [23,24]. This behavior observed for LaFe0.5Ni0.5O3 and LaFe0.5Co0.5O3 may be attributed to an inhibitory effect on the reduction of nickel and cobalt due to the presence of non-reducible Fe (III) in the structure [26–28]. The N2 physisorption isotherms for the calcined perovskites and exsolved catalysts shown in Fig. 2 displayed a type II isotherm typical for nonporous materials [29,30]. The surface area (SBET) summarized in Table 1 indicates for the calcined perovskites similarly low values ranging from 3 to 5 m2g−1. Considering an error of 5–10 % in SBET, after the exsolution process an increase of twice of SBET value only for LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3, with no significant changes for the Fe-containing perovskites. These results are consistent with the previous discussion that the presence of Fe enhances the thermal stability of the perovskites. In contrast, the result observed for LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 suggest a partial loss of perovskite structure and the appearance of metallic phases. X-ray diffraction analyses were performed to characterize the crystalline structure of the materials before and after the exsolution process and their result is shown in Fig. 3. The XRD patterns of the half-substituted LaFe0.5Co0.5O3 and LaFe0.5Ni0.5O3 calcined perovskites and exsolved catalysts displayed a well-resolved and sharp diffractions peak located at 2θ = 33°, 41°, 47° and 59° values, attributed to diffraction lines of crystal perovskite structure without the presence of segregated phases after calcination of the solids at 700 °C and exsolved treatment [31]. Based on reference powder diffraction data, calcined LaFe0.5Co0.5O3 and LaFe0.5Ni0.5O3 perovskites and exsolved catalysts presented an orthorhombic crystal structure [32]. This result corroborated that Fe-containing perovskites were not reducible in H2 at 500 °C and confirms that the presence of Fe (III) avoids the formation of metallic nanoparticles by exsolution treatment. A different behavior is seen for LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3, whereas the diffraction lines of the calcined perovskite correspond to a rhombohedral LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 structure [33] and after the ex-solution process, the diffraction lines of the perovskite structure disappeared and were replaced by poorly crystalline segregated phases. In fact, the absence of diffraction peaks at 2θ= 33°, 41°, 47° and 59° indicates the partial disappearance of the perovskite structure and the appearance of poor crystalline phases of La(OH)3 (2θ= 28°, 40°, 49°) and La2O3 (2θ= 28°, 31°, 40°). 3.1.2 Catalytic activity The conversion of m-cresol and yield of products as a function of time at 200 °C and 50 bar of H2 pressure over the half-substituted exsolved catalysts are shown in Fig. 4. A blank test was performed which showed that m-cresol was unreactive in absence of catalyst and in presence of the half-substituted calcined perovskites at 200 °C and 50 bar of H2. Among the three exsolved catalysts, only LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 achieved complete m-cresol conversion within 1 h at 200 °C and 50 bar of H2, with 3-methycyclohexanol (MCol) as the main product. In contrast, the Fe-containing catalysts showed significantly lower activity (< 7 % m-cresol conversion after 4 h), likely due to poor reducibility under reaction conditions. Due to its superior performance, LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst was selected for further comparison with its pure counterpart to elucidate the origin of its enhanced activity. 3.2 Pure exsolved LaNiO3 and LaCoO3 and half substituted LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalysts 3.2.1 Characterization Fig. 3 shows the pure LaNiO3, LaCoO3, and half-substituted LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 calcined and exsolved diffraction patterns. The diffraction lines of the calcined LaNiO3, LaCoO3 and LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 in Fig. 3a correspond to a rhombohedral LaNiO3 (JCPDS 34–1181), LaCoO3 (JCPDS-ICDD 84–0848), and LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 structures [33]. Similar XRD patterns indicate that the substitution of 50 % of the B cation with a B´ cation with the same oxidation state and almost the same ionic radius did not modify the perovskite structure. After the exsolution process (Fig. 3b), the diffraction lines of the perovskite structure partially disappeared and were replaced by poorly crystalline segregated phases. The broad diffraction peaks at 2θ = 24°, 33°, 41° and 59° suggest the presence of La(OH)3 (2θ = 28, 40, 49°) and La2O3 (2θ = 28, 31, 40) [34]. Although exsolved catalysts may exhibit segregated phases, multiple studies report that the observed metallic nanoparticles predominantly arise from an exsolution process rather than random segregation. For an impregnated Ni-La2O3 catalyst, reduction leads to the transformation of NiO to Ni0, accompanied by a poorly crystalline perovskite structure. Here, the resulting Ni0 particles appear as loosely attached segregates on the oxide matrix [35]. In contrast, the reduction of LaNiO₃ induces the partial disappearance of perovskite reflections in the XRD pattern, along with the emergence of metallic Ni⁰ peaks. This behavior is characteristic of a topotactic transformation, in which Ni species are released from the B-site lattice positions of the perovskite. Consequently, the exsolved Ni nanoparticles are strongly anchored to the oxide matrix, an essential hallmark of the exsolution phenomenon. To better observe the presence of metallic Co0 (2θ = 44.2°, 51.5°, 75.9°) [36] and Ni0 (2θ = 44.5°, 51.8°, 76.5°) [37] species, the patterns of the exsolved catalysts are shown on an expanded scale in Fig. 3b. The well-resolved peaks in the patterns of pure LaCoO3 and LaNiO3 exsolved catalysts indicate the presence of metallic Co0 and Ni0, respectively, whereas the absence of sharp metallic reflections in the XRD patterns in the exsolved LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst, and the broad nature of the diffraction signals suggest the formation of highly dispersed or amorphous metallic nanoparticles. Given the co-existence of Co0 and Ni0 on the catalyst surface, it is possible that bimetallic Ni–Co entities or intermetallic clusters are formed during exsolution [14]. XPS analysis was conducted to investigate the surface composition of the exsolved LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst. For comparison purposes, LaCoO3 and LaNiO3 were also analyzed. The La 3d, Ni 2p, Co 2p and O 1 s, core-level spectra for the exsolved catalysts are displayed in Fig. 5. The binding energy (BE), their relative proportion (in parentheses) and atomic surface ratio are summarized in Table 2. It is observed that the La 3d5/2 spectra exhibited two main peaks at 834.8 and 838.9 eV, attributed to surface La3+ in perovskite structure and La2O3 surface phases, respectively. The Ni 2p3/2 spectra revealed two surface nickel species: metallic Ni0 at 852.0 eV and Ni2+ at 854.7 eV, along with a satellite peak at 859.0 eV, thus confirming the presence of surface Ni2+. Similarly, the Co 2p3/2 spectra showed both surface cobalt species: metallic Co0 at 778.2 eV and Co2+ at 780.9 eV, along with a satellite peak at 790.2 eV, thus corroborating the presence of Co2+ in CoO structure [25]. These results are in line with XRD results confirming the partial destruction of the perovskite structure and the appearance of segregate phases. Also, the effective creation of Ni0 and Co0 metals nanoparticles after the exsolution process at 500 °C is corroborated, in concordance with XRD results. In the case of the O 1 s spectra, the presence of lattice O2- associated with surface La2O3 (OL) at 528.1 eV, surface hydroxyl/carbonate groups (OHC) at 531.1 eV, and weakly bonded O2- (OW) species at 534.0 eV were observed [34]. A BE of C1s at 289.8 eV (not included) was observed for all the perovskites and corresponds to the presence of surface carbonates which originated from the La species. As is shown in Table 2, all exsolved catalysts display a highest relative proportion (shown in parenthesis) of OHC species, suggesting the formation of adsorbed carbonate over the surface of Ni0, Co0 and La3+. Furthermore, relative proportion of Ni0 and Co0 is much higher than the Ni2+ and Co2+ species for bimetallic LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 exsolved catalyst, suggesting that some Ni and Co species strongly interact with the surface structure. Moreover, the relative proportion of Ni0 species increased twice in the LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst in comparison with pure LaNiO3, thus confirming a cooperative effect between Co and Ni particles. Regarding the Ni0/Ni2+ and Co0/Co2+ atomic surface ratio, a higher atomic ratio was observed for bimetallic LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst in comparison with pure LaCoO3 and LaNiO3 catalysts, thus confirming a high Ni and Co metallic dispersion on the surface of the exsolved catalyst, in agreement with XRD results. Also, the atomic surface ratios confirm a higher amount of Ni0 rather than Co0 species in the surface of the catalyst. The detection of highly dispersed Ni0 and Co0 species, likely anchored to the oxide matrix as expected in exsolved systems, suggests the presence of strong metal–support interaction in the LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst. This could point toward the formation of highly dispersed bimetallic sites or even Ni–Co alloy-like domains, which are known to modify the electronic structure and enhance H–H bond dissociation. TEM micrographs and EDS elemental mapping of the exsolved LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst ( Fig. 6) show the presence of well-dispersed metallic nanoparticles anchored on the perovskite matrix, confirming the occurrence of thermally induced exsolution. The high-magnification image (Fig. 6b) confirms the socketed nature of these particles, characteristic of the exsolution process, ensuring strong metal–support interactions. The particle size distribution of the exsolved LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst (Fig. 6c), estimated from TEM micrographs, revealed an average particle diameter of 9.9 nm with a relatively broad distribution. The histogram indicates that most particles are below 15 nm, consisting of the high dispersion expected from the exsolution process. Elemental mapping reveals a homogeneous distribution of La, Co, Ni, and O, with Co and Ni co-localized on the nanoparticles, suggesting the possible formation of bimetallic Ni–Co domains. These results are consistent with XRD, which indicated partial loss of the perovskite structure and the appearance of poor crystalline metallic phases, and with XPS, which evidenced a high proportion of Ni0 and Co0 species on the surface, confirming a controlled surface migration of the B-site cations without significant loss, supporting the structural stability of the perovskite after the treatment. H2-TPR profile of pure and substituted calcined perovskite are shown in Fig. 1. It can be observed that LaCoO3 displays two reduction peaks centered at 412 °C corresponding to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ species, while at 560 °C is associated with the reduction of Co2+ to Co0 species. For LaNiO3, three reduction peaks at low temperature correspond to the reduction of NiO species with weak interactions in the perovskite structure, meanwhile the peaks at 340 °C and 500 °C are associated with the reduction of Ni3+ to Ni2+. For the substituted LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 three deconvoluted peaks were observed (Figure S1), with a reduction profile which is in the middle of reduction temperature displayed by pure LaCoO3 and LaNiO3. This result indicates a cooperative effect between nickel and cobalt species in the bimetallic LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst. The acid properties were analyzed by NH3-TPD ( Fig. 7) to characterize the acidity of the catalysts. The desorption profiles can be used to determine the acid strength of the sites: weak acid sites (< 300 °C), medium acid sites (between 300 °C and 500 °C), and strong acid sites (> 500 °C) [38]. Fig. 7 shows that the corresponding NH3-TPD profiles display a narrow signal in the range of 620–690 °C, which indicate the presence of strong acid sites related to the Lewis acid character of oxygen vacancies, the basic character of the lanthanum species [38], and unsaturated species of B-site cation that can act as weak Lewis’s acid sites [34,36]. From the quantification of the corresponding decomposition curve of NH3 profiles, the total acid sites were estimated and it shown in Table 1. The obtained values indicate a slight decrease in the amount of acid sites, indicating a cooperative effect between metal Co-Ni particles in the LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst. 3.2.2 Catalytic activity The conversion of m-cresol and yield of products as a function of time at 200 °C and 50 bar of H2 pressure over the pure LaNiO3 and LaCoO3 exsolved catalysts (Figure S2) shows a larger conversion of m-cresol reaching a value up to 90 % after 1 h of reaction for LaCoO3, and over LaNiO3 only is reached a 30 % at same reaction time. For pure LaCoO3 catalyst, the increasing appearance of MChe after 2 h of reaction is consistent with the intermediacy of MCol. For LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 (Fig. 4) MCol also presented an intermediate behavior although the products distribution differed clearly from those for LaCoO3 and LaNiO3. This suggests the existence of different active sites which may be linked to the formation of intermetallic species during the reduction process. The presence of large amount of MCol demonstrates that hydrogenation occurred rapidly over the LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst. Furthermore, the low presence of phenol and toluene indicates a non-significative demethylation (DME) and direct deoxygenation (DDO) pathway on the acid sites. The product distribution suggests that MCona may also serve as an intermediate in route to MCol. Based on literature, and the significative quantified observed reaction products, a reaction scheme is proposed for the catalytic transformation of m-cresol over the exsolved catalysts ( Scheme 1). The transformation proceeds through successive hydrogenation steps facilitated by the active metallic sites derived from the exsolution of Ni and Co nanoparticles. The first stage of the reaction involves the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, leading to the formation of partially hydrogenated intermediates, such as 3-methylcyclohexenol (MCenol). Further hydrogenation produces 3-methylcyclohexanol (MCol) as the principal saturated alcohol product. In presence of acid sites, at long reaction times may occur the formation of 3-methylcyclohexene (MChe), which at higher hydrogen pressures is transformed to 3-methylcyclohexane (MCha). This product distribution reflects the dual functionality of the catalyst; thus, Ni and Co sites not only facilitate ring hydrogenation but may promote acid dehydration at severe reaction conditions. The mechanistic interpretation proposed in Scheme 1 can be better understood in the framework of competing DDO and HYD pathways. The predominant formation of 3-methylcyclohexanol (MCol) and the low yield of toluene or phenol indicate that the reaction predominantly proceeds via aromatic ring hydrogenation. The negligible production of toluene supports the hypothesis that DDO pathway is not favored under the reaction conditions. This pathway preference is likely driven by the metallic nature of the Ni0 and Co0 particles and the lack of strong Brønsted acidity on the catalyst surface. The specific catalytic activity, based on the initial reaction rate (x10−3 molm-cresolgcat −1s−1), and the yield of products at a conversion level of 10 % is shown in Fig. 8. The enhanced catalytic performance of LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst (Fig. 8a), is attributed to the catalyst-substrate interaction because of the half substitution of Ni and Co in the B site. From the evidence of metallic Ni-Co interactions from H2-TPR, XPS and TEM characterization results in LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 and the fact that the catalytic behavior was not an intermediate behavior of the catalytic behavior of LaCoO3 and LaNiO3, it cannot be ruled out a synergetic effect between metallic Ni0 and Co0. Recent studies that emphasis the critical role of dynamic redox cycling and interfacial oxygen vacancies in exsolved perovskites systems for hydrogenation applications [14], highlight the importance of the exsolution process. Therefore, the enhanced hydrogenation activity and structural resilience upon redox cycling exsolved LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst is related to its capacity to reversibly accommodate surface oxygen species without compromising metallic nanoparticle dispersion. Regarding the selectivity of products at 10 % of m-cresol conversion (Fig. 8.b), MCol the main product over all the catalysts, indicates that the main reaction pathway was direct hydrogenation of m-cresol to form MCol. The effect of H2 pressure on the conversion of m-cresol and product distribution over the LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst at 200 °C is shown in Fig. 9. The experiment was conducted with fresh catalyst in every catalytic run. It can be observed that an increase in H2 pressure from 20 to 30 bar led to a clear increase in m-cresol conversion, where 100 % of m-cresol conversion was achieved; however, a further increase to 50 bar had no effect on the conversion. With regards to the yield of products, MCol was the main product regardless of the H2 pressure, although a slight increase of the products MChe, MCha, phenol, benzene can be observed at higher pressures. The effect of the reaction temperature at 50 bar on the conversion of m-cresol and the product distribution over the LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst is shown in Fig. 10. The experiments were similarly performed with fresh catalyst in every catalytic run. The results show that the conversion of m-cresol reaches 100 % in a shorter time when the temperature increases from 150 °C to 170 °C. On the other hand, MCol was the main product at three temperatures studied. The yield values obtained indicate that the hydrodeoxygenation capacity of the catalyst is favorable at higher temperatures. From the obtained activity data, the apparent activation energy (Eaa) was calculated from the slope of the Arrhenius equation plot (Figure S3). The data exhibit a linear behavior, indicating that the reaction follows Arrhenius kinetic within the studied temperature range. From the slope of the linear fit, the apparent activation energy was calculated to be 31 kJ/mol. This value is consistent with typical hydrogenation reactions over metal catalysts and supports the hypothesis that the rate-determining step involves hydrogen addition to the aromatic ring or subsequent surface rearrangement prior to C–O bond cleavage. The relatively low activation energy observed for LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 highlights the effectiveness of the exsolved catalyst structure in facilitating hydrogen activation and transfer. The presence of Ni0 and Co0 nanoparticles exsolved from the perovskite matrix likely provides a high density of active sites with optimal adsorption energy for both m-cresol and hydrogen molecules. This thermal stability reinforces the catalytic robustness of the exsolved LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 system for potential industrial application in biomass-derived phenol transformations. 3.3 Recycling of the exsolved LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst The operational stability of the most active catalyst (LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3) was evaluated through recycling tests and the results are shown in Fig. 11. After each recycling, the catalyst was recovered by filtration, washed with 40.0 mL of methanol, and dried at 110 °C for 12 h. It is noticeable that no deactivation occurred after 5 reaction cycles (Figure S4) maintaining the m-cresol conversion and yield of MCol after 4 h of each recycling test. Post-reaction elemental analysis, carried out for the catalyst used in the 5th recycle compiled in Table 3, shows that the contents of cobalt and nickel extent remained the same after reaction, indicating no leaching of metallic species. XPS measurements of the post-reaction catalyst were also carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 12. For comparison the scale of the y axis of the XP spectra is the same of Fig. 5. The main difference is observed in the O 1 s core-level spectra, in which the post-reaction catalyst displayed a higher proportion of oxygen species related to surface molecular water (BE higher than 532 eV) as is seen in Table 4. The LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst, after exsolution, exhibits enhanced catalytic properties due to the formation of well-dispersed metallic nanoparticles anchored onto a robust perovskite matrix. This architecture contributes to improved hydrogen activation, increased surface accessibility, and sustained activity over multiple reaction cycles. The synergistic interaction between Ni and Co further enhances the selectivity and efficiency of the catalytic system. 4 Conclusions A series of half substituted LaFe0.5Ni0.5O3, LaFe0.5Co0.5O3 and LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 perovskites were used as precursors to synthesize exsolved catalysts for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of m-cresol at 200 °C and 50 bar of H2 pressure. Significant differences in reducibility were observed among the perovskites, primarily influenced by the presence of Fe. Furthermore, the non-Fe-containing (LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3) exsolved catalyst was the most active presented the formation of surface metallic Co0 and Ni0 species. However, the possible formation of highly dispersed intermetallic Ni0-Co0 cannot be ruled out. The catalytic evaluation revealed 3-methylcyclohexanol as the main reaction product on all the catalysts. The exsolved LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst exhibited the highest initial reaction rate and HYD activity, that increases with the H2 pressure from 20 to 50 and the reaction temperature between 150 °C and 200 °C. Noticeable, the exsolved LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst did not show any loss in catalytic activity after 5 cycles without regeneration process, which was linked to a lack of leaching of Ni and Co species by post-reaction characterization. The structural evolution, together with the stability and catalytic performance observed, supports that metal particles are exsolved rather than simply segregated, in agreement with exsolution behavior described for perovskite-derived systems CRediT authorship contribution statement Catherine Sepulveda: Writing – review & editing, Methodology. coredata.dc:description: Half-substituted perovskites LaFe0.5Ni0.5O3, LaFe0.5Co0.5O3 and LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 were used as precursors to synthesize, by an exsolution process, reduced catalysts for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of m-cresol at 200 °C and 30 bar H2 pressure. The calcined perovskites and exsolved catalysts were characterized by AAS, H2-TPR, N2 physisorption, XRD, XPS, TEM and NH3-TPD techniques. The characterization results show large differences in the reducibility of perovskites in the presence or absence of Fe. In the case of the exsolved catalyst without Fe content (LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3), the formation of metallic Co0 and Ni0 is detected, while the exsolved catalysts containing Fe (LaFe0.5Co0.5O3, LaFe0.5Ni0.5O3) were not reducible in H2 below 500 °C. The higher m-cresol conversion, initial reaction rate and hydrogenation (HYD) activity of the exsolved LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst were attributed to the presence of highly dispersed surface species of metallic Co0 and Ni0. The formation of the major product, 3-methylcyclohexanol, over the LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst was independent of the reaction temperature in the range of 150 – 200 °C. However, the hydrogenation activity increased with increasing H2 pressure between 20 and 50 bar. The exsolved LaCo0.5Ni0.5O3 catalyst shows no loss of catalytic activity after 5 cycles without regeneration, and post-reaction characterization demonstrates that the surface composition remains stable after five reaction cycles, with no detectable leaching of nickel and cobalt.
